newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: ARGENTINA DENIES DIVIDEND AND INTEREST TAX REPORTS.
newsitem.headline: ARGENTINA DENIES DIVIDEND AND INTEREST TAX REPORTS.

text.p: Argentina's tax policy chief Monday denied press reports that the government was considering slapping new taxes on income from share dividends and interest from fixed-term bank deposits.
"We are not studying any taxation changes for '97 or '98," the Undersecretary for Tax Policy, Guillermo Rodriguez Use, told reporters when asked if the newspaper reports were true.

Various Argentine newspapers carried front-page reports Monday saying that Vito Tanzi, head of the International Monetary Fund's fiscal department, had recommended Economy Minister Roque Fernandez make "corrections" in tax policy.
"The negative impact of taxes on dividends and interest has been exaggerated," Tanzi told Clarin newspaper in an interview published Monday.
But the new financial daily Buenos Aires Economico quoted Rodriguez Use saying "financial assets are very difficult to tax" and carried the risk of scaring away investors.

He told reporters at the Economy Ministry that the only changes in tax policy now under consideration are extensions to income tax and the proposed "mono-tax" to simplify the tax structure for small and medium-sized businesses.
